comments.text:
The second problema is also present in dutch and in some occasion in 
Italian. 

In Italy the problem is limited from 11 to 16, but with plenty of 
stylistical variations:

11 = undici (uno = 1, dieci = 10) *not unOdici
12 = dodici (due = 2) *Not dUEdici
13 = tredici (tre = 3)
14 = quattordici (quattro = 4) *Not quattROdici
15 = quindici (cinque =5)  *Absolutely not cinquedici
16 = sedici (sei = 6) *Not seIdici

from 17 to 99 we return to the normal numbering 
17 = diciAssette (sette = 7)
18 = diciotto (otto= 8)
19 = diciANnove (nove = 9)
but we still use stylistical variations to the rule.
comments.author: clinker85

comments.text:
And when saying fractional numbers, like the sprint world record time in 
the video, or other scientific numbers, we tend to spell out the single 
digits after the decimal point (or rather, the comma), e.g. "zehn komma 
fünf drei" (10,53). But when we're talking about money, we tend to *not* 
spell out single digits. E.g. if the same number was the price of an item, 
we would say "zehn Euro dreiundfünfzig". So context is important.

The same is true with four digit numbers. If it was any number, e.g. 1970, 
we would say "eintausend neunhundert siebzig" (one thousand nine hundred 
seventy). But if it's a year number, we would say "neunzehnhundert siebzig" 
(nineteen hundred seventy). *Except* for years after 2000. Then people 
again say "zweitausend fünf" (two thousand five) instead of "zwanzig 
hundert fünf" (twenty hundred and five).

I have sympathies for people who have to learn our language..

comments.text:
+Gene Hunter   Hi Gene, could not find your answer to my answer here so I 
post mine there. You may be right, giving priority to Hierarchy may be 
typically British (with Quenn, Lords, Sirs etc ...) while giving priority 
to legibillity (related to aesthetic) may be typically French (artistic and 
luxury domains, LVMH etc ...) Maybe. . . Each one his perception. I don't 
know your age, I am 70, and I can tell you that my first writings in 
Tangier were laid on a not-so-white paper (rather light brown, coming from 
Casablanca, not from Paris or London) with a lot of inclusions. And paper 
was probably worse when most Continental countries enfavored the use of a 
much visible mark (coma), while.British, accordind to your opinion, 
enfavoured the hierarchy.
However I don't see why the hierarchy in text should apply to numbers. In 
Arab, Persian, and Hebrew, writing is from right to left, but not the 
numbers which are left to right, applying a different rule totwo different 
domains.
Note that final points are almost invisible on my screen (no problem, a 
sentence starts with a "Majuscule" (upper-case) or next paragraph), while 
the comas (rythm of the sentence) are legible, and a coma misplaced can 
make a lot of difference in some meaning (so, coma may be more important 
than a point, in that case).
For what concerns the shape of the "1" and the "7" in French, we just 
respect (in hand-writing and some fonts) the original code built-in the 
figures, ages ago (one angle, two angles ... seven angles ...).  Funny to 
see that, on this particular point, WE, French, stick to traditions ! God 
save the 7 and have a nice day !
comments.author: crunch642

comments.text:
+crunch642

Hello crunch642,
If you’re saying that your Tangier experience with the Brits inspired you 
to agree with their use of the hierarchy of commas and dots .... but that 
the difference between French and Brits hand-writing the 1s and 7s caused 
you to change your mind, I must tell you that sounds so funny … and so very 
French.

Dot versus comma, 1s and 7s, in my opinion, is a cultural thing and it has 
very little, if anything to do with legibility.

As for dirty paper causing legibility problems or confusion in the early 
days, I don’t quite see your point (pun intended).
If a ‘dot’ could be mistaken for a ‘comma’ due to imperfections on the 
paper, then you have problems no matter which marker you choose.

Allow me to explain with an example: You write “1.000” if you want to write 
ONE THOUSAND. Agreed?
According to you if the paper is not squeaky clean (fly shit) the dot ‘.’ 
might be read as a comma i.e. 1,000
Now it reads simply reads as 1 with 3 zeros behind the decimal mark. That 
is NOT one thousand. As I said, it’s a problem.
Anyway, the first use of the “comma” and “full stop” goes back to the 15th 
century with the introduction of printing.

Quite frankly, I consider it rather unimportant what people in different 
countries choose for their decimal marker. Nobody is right and no-none is 
wrong!

I am a lot more interested in the fact that people can’t agree on universal 
standards of anything from commas and dots to decimalisation, weight, 
distance, capacity, speed, temperature etc etc.

It’s rather amusing that you state “After some reflexion” you concluded 
that … …! Did the reflecting involve any research at all? Perhaps you have 
evidence that might support your conclusion that the structure of a 
sentence has nothing to do with the structure of figures? If not, then it’s 
merely your opinion. Do we agree?

The majority of the people around the world may even disagree with you 
considering that most people use the opposite method of separating 
thousands and decimals from the Europeans.

Whatever you conclude or believe is fine with me, honestly! I have no 
problem if it makes sense to you however I am questioning why it should be 
logical for punctuation marks in the written language and punctuation marks 
in mathematical expressions to be diametrically opposed to each other. It 
is illogical!

I have evidence to prove that at least one French hypermarket chain 
advertises its prices in both ways. I doubt that it was a mistake but they 
are showing different articles and their prices. The decimals of the prices 
are separated with a point on one article and with a comma on the other ON 
THE SAME PAGE! Chapeau! Evolution!?

‘Coma’ and ‘Comma’! Michael Schumacher was in a “coma” for a few months! 
Virgule = Comma!
Incidentally, you say you are 70!? I could’ve sworn you were 72!
It may be a little late but anyway, Happy New Year to you and surtout une 
bonne santé!
comments.author: Gene Hunter

comments.text:
+Gene Hunter
Hi Gene, just too late for Happy New Year, so ... Back to decimal 
point/coma.
When I was a young scholar (living in Tangier, International city, I had 
British school-friends in the French school) I was thinking exactly same as 
you (the hierarchy of coma and point in writing). Then I have been thinking 
also about the way to write 1 and 7 in English or French. And I realized 
that the french logic was NOT based on hierarchy, but on "LEGIBILITY" 
("lisibilité". did I translate it properly ?).
This is why, for instance, our ONE has a little "nose", unlike US which is 
just a vertical bar which can be confused with a slash (divide symbol). Our 
SEVEN  has a "neck-tie" to make it not confusable with our ONE. Today, 
handwriting is over, we all write on keybards and chose a variety of fonts 
and styles, and the digital displays have standardized the figures.
SO, back to the Decimal sign, whatever it is (coma, dot, other), it was 
important that it should not be confused with a natural spot (or "fly 
shit") on rough paper. Today, the cheapest paper is absolutely spotless and 
bright white, but when I was young (I am 70) it was not so !). And the fact 
is that the coma is more visible than a dot. They could have chosen  " or 
,,  even more visible, but they were happy with a single coma.
Concerning The dot (point) between thousands, it is NOT used. Instead, 
there is a SPACE. So, the french "hierarchy", if any, is "space" between 
thousands and "coma" before the decimal section..And after some reflexion, 
I came to the conclusion that the structure of a sentence had nothing to do 
with the structure of the figures, it had NO reason to follow it, only some 
characters are similar.
It is like English, Irish, and Portuguese, they use the same latin letters 
but use them differently. (some day you will explain me the TWO 
pronounciations of the "i", in English ONLY (in NO other language).
Last point ( :-) ) about decimals : often, the decimals are written in 
smaller size, and then nobody cares about point or coma, no possible 
mistake.
Have a nice day.

I think it's mostly the case of Anglo-Saxons vs rest of the world that 
causes most problems - including accidents. Because the English speaking 
countries dominate the world in many areas, they seem reluctant to adapt to 
the rest of the world and want to keep all their idiosyncratic measuring 
and typing systems and conventions (the US being the main culprit here) and 
forcing them upon all of us ("a 5-inch screen" instead of a 12.5 cm screen, 
and all those feet and Fahrenheits, which I constantly have to convert). 
Most areas of the world don't seem to have a problem with the metric system 
and we would all be happily using it in each area if it weren't for the 
domination of English-speaking countries (and the language itself). That's 
why we have to deal with illogical ridiculousness such as "12/23/14", i.e. 
month/day/year) coming from the US. If we could all sit down and just 
choose the standard that is a. most logical or b. most prevalent, we would 
all have much easier lives. Whether we should use a comma or a dot before 
decimal places is admittedly not so obvious; it might be more logical to 
use a dot (though I don't quite get that logic), but if we consider what I 
stated in my initial comment - that most European languages use the comma, 
we might just as well decide that the English-speaking world should 
conform; why should all the other countries have to switch?

In language, when writing a sentence, you will use commas and full stops,

whole number that is not a fraction.

comments.text:
Well, I think it is more logical to use a comma to seperate numbers, 
because in grammar, a full stop is used to end a sentence, while a comma is 
used to introduce a relative clause. So in "10.273" the full stop would 
indicate that the number stops after it, while "10,273" would indicate, 
that it is a part of 10. However, this doesn't make sense when you're using 
a full stop at the same time to separate three digits.
comments.author: OrenthalJunior

comments.text:
+LOIZOS V
Yes of course Indians, Australians and many others got it from the Brits 
because of the Commonwealth However I am sure the Japanese didn’t get it 
from the Brits although I am not so sure about the Americans.
Anyway, where they got it from seems irrelevant. That said, it’s no 
surprise the world is in such a mess when nations can’t even agree on the 
use of a simple decimal mark, let alone decimalisation.

You may disagree with me but this is MY logic.
In the written language people often use commas and full stops, right?
Why does one use a comma? When we want to make a pause within the same 
sentence!
When do we use the full stop? At the end of a completed sentence!
Therefore, it’s illogical to do exactly the opposite with numbers.

Integers are complete, whole numbers. They are not fractions and therefore 
it seems logical that integers and fractions should be separated by a full 
stop and thousands (the integer) are shown with commas. I would not even 
find it illogical to display thousands by using space, like so 12 345.25
Incidentally the Brits originally used an "interpunct", also known as 
"mid-dot" as the decimal separator, like so 99·95 however very few printing 
presses were equipped to handle it, so it died a death.

comments.text:
+TheLogicJunkie Esoterica? I'm a linguist, not a mathematician. Language is 
not logical, and it has hardly ever been, which is why there are so many 
different sorts of languages with so many different grammar types and 
rules. So is made a language that almost any word around you can move 
without losing the sense. And that's not how logic works. If logic defined 
language, then all languages would have the same, stable syntax. But they 
don't. Should the verb be at the beginning, middle or end of the sentence? 
Should the object be before or after said verb? It's not defined by logic. 
Vocabulary isn't defined by logic. Sure, language is used to express 
logical thoughts, but it's not the other way around, logic doesn't define a 
language and it never has, because it's all patterns that were created by 
groups of people that evolved over time, not patterns that were decided 
because "they made more sense". They were used like that because that's 
just how the language evolved. Which is why the French will keep on saying 
soixante-dix and you're just plain rude for trying to force your 
stubbornness onto a language. Words are stronger than you.
comments.author: cornemuz

includes a reference to logic as quoted below!
It was in the 17th century, under the influence of Vaugelas and Ménage, 
that the Academy and other authors of dictionaries definitively adopted the 
forms ‘soixante-dix’, ‘quatre-vingts’, ‘quatre-vingt-dix’ instead of 
‘septante’, ‘octante’, ‘nonante’.
It is worth noting however that the words ‘septante’, ‘octante’, ‘nonante’ 
are included in all editions of the dictionary of the “Académie française”.

>>>>Still recommended by the “Instructions Officielles de 1945” to 
facilitate learning calculus, they remain in use some parts of Eastern and 
Southern France, as well as in Acadia.<<<<

Quote from “Instructions Officielles de 1945”:
Les noms des nombres présentent, comme l'on sait, des anomalies; il peut 
être avantageux d'employer d'abord les noms qui seraient logiques:
dix-un, au lieu de onze;
dix-deux au lieu de douze;
dix-six, au lieu de seize.
De même utiliser septante, octante et nonante au
lieu de soixante-dix, quatre-vingts et quatre-vingt-dix.
Des leçons complémentaires de vocabulaire feront ensuite correspondre à ces 
noms théoriques les noms de notre français courant.
UNQUOTE. Source : http://jl.bregeon.perso.sfr.fr/Programmes_primaire1945.pdf

They are official in Belgium and Switzerland (except, however, ‘octante’, 
which was replaced by ‘quatre-vingts’ and ‘huitante’ - in Switzerland – for 
common use as well as in teaching and in administrative texts).
Nothing prevents their use, but in France, they are perceived as regional 
or outdated.

comments.text:
+TheLogicJunkie It has nothing to do with the Belgian, the French have 
counted this way since long before Belgium even existed. They used to count 
twenty by twenty, hence "quatre-vingt", and the latin numbers only appeared 
recently in History (about the 18th century), and they kept the bigger 
numbers as they were because they were easier to count with. 90 -> 
quatre-vingt-dix, is a calculus in itself and when you do math it's easier 
to break down than 90 -> nonante. 
The Belgian changed those things to make themselves distinct from the 
French. That's actually the irony. Because it's not their language per se, 
they don't have to respect it as much as the French do. And it's still 
easier to count big numbers with quatre-vingt-dix rather than nonante tbh.

+smjpl Well, logically you cannot compare a single decimal to a double 
decimal; it is a basic rule in (French only?) mathematics. The '.5' in 
'3.5' has to be seen as a '50'. You just add a '0' so you can fairly 
compare two double decimals. . ----> 3.5 becomes 3,50 (trois virgule 
cinquante) which is indeed > 3,35. When 3,5 is written, it implies 3,50. 
Calculators also remove unnecessary 'zeros'. If I remember well, we call 
those zeros 'imaginary'; even when they are not there, they ARE there! LOL

Another way, would be to only consider the first decimal of each number, to 
compare them: 3,5 > 3,3(5).

Makes perfect sense, bien sûr! ... No? ;))

comments.text:
He's saying Danish verbs don't inflect according to person (or number). 
They still inflect according to tense and mood (ex., present, past, 
imperative, etc.).

The result is that (in Danish) you always need to include the pronoun. In 
languages that inflect fully (or almost fully), you can omit the pronoun 
(i.e., you don't need to say "I", "you", "he", etc., because that is 
already implied by the verb itself). This is what happens in Spanish, 
Portuguese and Italian, for example. 

Other languages, like French and English, have limited inflection. So while 
you can say "am hungry" (and it's clear that you are talking about 
yourself, even without the "I"), if you say simply "are late", it's unclear 
if you mean "you", "we" or "they" (even with "you", it's unclear if you 
mean singular or plural, so people tend to add more words like "guys" to 
clarify that). And, since the pronoun is required in those cases, English 
and French speakers end up using it for every person (even for the ones 
where they wouldn't need it).

comments.text: Tl;DR
comments.author: Lucija lux

comments.text:
Most people from the continent, including the French will find this rather 
embarrassing because you sound like an Anglophobe with a strong prejudice 
and confused factual knowledge.

You say “They [the British] write “wierd”! The irony of that is that the 
English word is “weird”!

You say “They don't have the same measurement system as the rest of Europe!”
The United Kingdom completed its legal partial transition to the metric 
system (referred to as "SI" from the “French Système International 
d'Unités”) in 1995, so the only acceptable excuse you could possibly offer 
is that the transition isn’t complete and that some people, mainly old 
folks in the UK haven’t been able to adopt it.

That however is another ironic trap you fell into because you cannot deny 
that many French people still, today in 2015, talk in old “francs”, some 
even use the archaic “ancient francs”. Furthermore, many shops and 
supermarkets print bills/receipts in Euros AND in Francs, even though 
you’ve used the Euro for just about 15 years.

“They [the British] have their own currency when most of Europe has the 
euro…”
So do Bulgaria, Croatia, Czech Republic, Denmark, Hungary, Poland, Romania, 
Sweden who are EU members but do not use the euro.

It makes no sense to blame the Brits for staying out of the Euro 
considering their Pound Sterling doesn't look that bad compared to the 
troubled Euro. Their economy also shows more potential in the immediate 
future than any continental rival.

So, just accept that your comment simply was a knee-jerk reaction to 
irrational feelings towards the British people.

Incidentally, I am not British but I love their island. They may be crazy 
but they are far from being lunatics. They can't be worse than the French, 
or can they?

I took French immersion back in elementary school (common thing in Canada - 
half the classes are in French, half are in English), and while my French 
isn't great, somehow I feel pretty comfortable with French numbers.

The way the French say the year is also kind of interesting.  It also 
varies; I'm not sure what the convention is in France, but in Canadian 
French, 1996 could be "dix neuf cent quatre-vingt soixante", which is 
roughly "nineteen hundred ninety six", similar to the English.  You might 
also hear "mille neuf cent quantre-vingt soixante", which is "one thousand 
nine hundred ninety six".  Sounds clunky in English, but it rolls off the 
tongue in French﻿

top_comment.text:
En France, la forme l'emporte sur le fond (esprit > pragmatique).  
Soixante-dix sonne mieux que Septante, Quatre-vingt sonne mieux que 
Octante,etc... 
La langue anglaise est logique, la langue française favorise le goût, 
l'apparence.
En ce qui concerne la virgule au lieu du point, cela est du au fait que 
dans la langue française, la virgule a une valeur symbolique inférieure au 
point. Elle est donc utilisée comme un appendice subséquent. Par contre le 
point, par sa symbolique majeure est utilisée pour signifier l'importance 
du nombre.
Ne parlons pas du passé composé selon l'auxiliaire être avoir...:-)
Beau travail en tout cas!﻿

Steph,
Surement un rapprochement vers les racines latines

vingt-dix : trente
deux-vingt : quarante
deux vingt dix : cinquante
trois-vingt : soixante.
trois-vingt-dix : soixante-dix ou septante
quatre-vingt : quatre-vingt ou huitante
quatre-vingt-dix : quatre-vingt-dix ou nonante

Cela dit, demeure le débat méta-physique :
Pourquoi  soixante-dix versus septante ?
Pourquoi  quatre-vingt versus huitante ?
Pourquoi quatre-vingt-dix versus nonante ?

Ben perso, je pense que ce fut une question de goût, de sonorité (cf mon

Quant au goût, il est de l'ordre de l'acculturation voire de l'appartenance.

+Laurent Laborde As far as ambiguity goes, I'd say English and Japanese 
beat French easily. For different reasons; English has so many homographs 
and relies so much on phrasal expressions that punctuation or cadence can 
completely alter the meaning of a sentence (either deliberately or by 
mistake), and Japanese is vague both by design (fuzzy meanings) and in 
usage (passive voice, self-effacement, etc.).

But, going back to French, "espace" doesn't really have a different 
*meaning* when it's feminine (unless you're talking about some obscure 
usage I'm not aware of). It's just traditional to treat it as feminine when 
talking about text spacing, and masculine in other contexts; it still means 
"space".

comments.text:
+crunch642
 Two Vowels : One "rule" if any, is  to avoid having an ending vowel 
followed by a word starting with the same vowel. For instance, instead 
saying "Je vais à Avignon [or Arles ...]", one should say "Je vais EN 
Avignon", but this is no longer respected (it has another justification for 
Avignon, which is not only a city, but was once a State-City when Popes 
moved there from Rome).. I would say "Je vais en Alabama" (= the state) 
but  "Je vais à Athens", or Albertville ...(- cities), and would find weird 
to say "Je vais EN Albertville". There are other "rules", with more 
exceptions than standars cases, as usual !
comments.author: crunch642

comments.text:
+Ivan Warren
 Hi, I find your comments (both) quite interresting, and you are probably 
close to the explanation (mainly the open vowel of "un"). Still, your point 
that Vinteu is unambiguous with Vintin means that you did not hear people 
from Anduze (pron. An'du-zÔ) grumbling/mumbling the last "sound" of both 
words ! :-)  ;-)
For the pace/rythm, it applies well to South of France ("langue d'Oc") 
where all the 21 to 29 are said on 3 legs (Vin-té-un, Vin-teu-deu ...), 
while in the "langue d'Oil" it is rather 3 legs for 21 = Vin-té-un, and 2 
legs only for 22, 23, 24 ... = Vin'n-deu, Vin'n-troi, Vin'n-kat etc ... (I 
write Vin like Vin'n to show a (very) slight sustain of the final "n").
 Well, have a nice day, Warren. Je vous souhaite une belle journée (I 
prefer "belle" rather than the more common "bonne", "nice" rather than 
"good", a mater of personnal taste ! ).

comments.author: Ivan Warren

comments.text:
Hi, Ivan Warren, if I may provide my reflexions on the subjects you raise :
For "Vingt ET un" (versus "Vingt deux") I guess that it comes fluently in 
Vingt ET un, pronounced "Vin-té-un", and could not be pronounced shorter 
(Vint-un is shorter, but misspronounced it sounds like "Vinte" pronounced 
with the accent of South of France means 20, not 21), while "Vin'té-deux" 
became "Vind-deu", shorter, and yet not confused with any other counting. I 
suppose this is the laziness of language, tending to find the shortest way. 
But it is just my guess.
For the dates, it is not always like you say (and you took a bad example !).
We say "Mille huit-cent" or "Dixhuit cent" equally. Just ask a French of my 
generation (70 y.o., today I don't know what they learn) : Marignan ??? the 
answer is "quinze cent quinze" and you would probably say "fifteen fifteen" 
without any "hundred" (1515 is the battle of Marignan, won by François 1er 
in Italy) and no one will say "Mille cinq cent quinze". But we always say 
"Mille xx" if it is LESS than 11xx (do you say "ten hundred"???), then  If 
it is equal or  more than 11xx, we say  equally, "Onze cent xx" or "Mille 
cent xx", with a preference to "Onze cent", "Douze cent", Treize cent" 
...It takes the same time to say "Dix-huit cent xx" than say "Mille huit 
cent xx".so it's up to everyone.
This goes up to "Dix-neuf cent xx". Then for 2014 we say "Deux mille 
quatorze", and now "Deux mille quinze", NOT "vingt cent quatorze" or "Vingt 
cent quinze" !!!.
For 2243, I don't think we will ever say "Vingt-deux cent quarante trois", 
but rather "Deux mille deux cent quarante trois".

As a French, there's also something that used to bother me when I was 
counting numbers the English way.
It's a problem with really big numbers. For example : 1 000 000 (or 
1,000,000) is a million in English (French : un million)
But : 1 000 000 000 (or 1,000,000,000) is a billion in English (French : un 
milliard) and this is very annoying because :
1 000 000 000 000 (or 1,000,000,000,000) is a trillion (French : un 
billion).
The problem is that we are adding another ending to million to make it a 
thousand more : milliard.
And it goes on with billion, billiard, trillion, trillard, etc.
We are using the big scale while you are using the small one.
If you want more information about it : 
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Long_and_short_scales
Otherwise, I really liked this video and I'm happy to be born in mille neuf 
cent quatre-vingt-dix-huit (1998)﻿

comments.text:
+Julef does some stuff why do you say “ No, it’s completely false … ?”

The short numeric scale:
1 million (10^6) 1 billion (10¨9) 1 trillion (10^12) 1 quadrillion (10^15) 
1 quintillion (10^18) 1 sextillion (10^21) etc. etc.

The long numeric scale:
1 million (10^6) 1 MILLIARD (10¨9) 1 BILLION (10^12) 1 BILLIARD (10^15) 1 
TRILLION (10^18) 1 TRILLIARD (10^21) etc. etc.
 
Surprise, surprise, the French have to be different again! So you count 
like this:
1 million (10^6) 1 milliard (10¨9) 1000 milliards (10^12) 1 million de 
milliards (10^15) 1 milliard de milliards (10^18) 1000 milliards de 
milliards (10^21) etc. etc.

Whichever way the French choose to count does NOT make everyone else wrong 
especially when you’ve developed your own very special way of counting 
large numbers in just multiples of “milliards”!

Could it be that the French are obsessed with the word "milliard"? It might 
explain why you’re still using “old-old francs” even after 15 years of 
using the Euro, When buying or selling properties you're talking in 
milliards of francs.

so, quite frankly, it says a lot about human inflexibility, which is a part 
of stupidity, if you consider that the world can't even agree on a 
universal system of counting.

often referred to as British and American scales in the English language. 
In 1974, the UK government of the UK fully adopted the short scale.

comments.text:
I think chinese number is somehow similar to English number. The only 
different is that they don't have the word of 11 to 19 (eleven twelve ... 
nineteen). They say "ten one"(11) "ten nine"(19) "two ten"(20) "three 
ten"(30) "seven ten two"(72) and so on.
For the big numbers, also similar to Eng's, they have words for hundred, 
thousand, and even "ten-thousand". They say 25360 as "two ten-thousand five 
thousand three hundred six ten". They are easy enough to read and write.
For decimal number, they are exactly same as English, use dot(.) and read 
decimal digits as individual number.
For bigger numbers (like 416,000), they also write comma as same as Eng's 
but they read it diffrenetly. Since they have "ten-thousand" as a word. 
They devide 4 digit as a part as 41|6000 and read as "four ten one 
ten-thousand six thousand". There are also words for digits that are 
multiple of 4 (3 in English). That's why I said they are similar to English 
number.
comments.author: skenming

comments.text:
I studied Mandarin in Elementary school (so I may be a tad off as it has 
been awhile). In Mandarin they have individualized names for 1-10. 
Following 10 is 10+1, so it would mirror if instead of saying eleven we 
instead said tenone, tentwo, tenthree, tenfour, etc. After the 10s are 
complete they move onto 2x10 (twenty) and they pronounce it twoten, 
following would be 2x10+1(21) twotenone, 2x10+2(22) twotentwo. 
More examples:
45: 4x10+5 - fourtenfive
70: 7x10 - seventen
89: 8x10+9 - eighttennine
Personally I found this way of counting easier as a non native speaker, 
compared to when I learned Spanish, as instead of needing to memorize a 
name for 1-10, and then a new name at every tenth interval you solely 
needed to lear 1-10 and then how to organize the numbers to get the 
intended value. 
I hoped this helped :)

odd until you remember that we say "Three-ten" as "Thirty" in English. The 
main difference is that, while we put the commas every 3 points 
(e.g.  299,792,458), the Chinese do so every 4 (e.g.  2,9979,2458). Also, 
they have a specific word for "Ten thousand" that they use in much the way 
we use "Thousand." When you think about the historical population 
differences, this isn't too surprising.

comments.text:
Try danish then.
Though we arrange it like the germans we have an extra twist:
"Ti" (10) means "ten"
"Tyve" (20) means "Second (ten)"
Tredive (30) means "Third (ten)"
"Fyrre" (40) means "Fourth (ten)"
Pretty much like german and english.
But then:
"Halvtreds" (50) is short for "Halvtredsindstyve" and means "Half of the 
third times second (ten)"
"Tres" (60) is short for "Tresindstyve" and means "Three times twenty"
"Halvfjerds" (70) is short for "Halvfjerdsindstyve" and means "Half of the 
fourth times second (ten)"
"Firs" (80) is short for "Firsindstyve" and means "Four times twenty"
"Halvfems" (90) is short for "Halvfemsindstyve" and means "Half of the 
fifth times second (ten)"

So 21 is "two tens one" in english, "one and two tens" in german, and "one 
and second (ten)" in danish (enogtyve)
Pretty much the same!

But where english and german follow the same syntax for 52: "five tens two" 
and "two and five tens" respectively,
it is "two and the half of the third times second (ten)" in danish 
(tooghalvtreds).

And 42874 is "two and fourth (ten) thousands eight hundred four and half of 
the fourth times second (ten)"

comments.text:
+GusBounas

In arab language we say :

- wahed (one) : 1 (contains one geometry angle)

- ithnane (two) : 2 angles

- thalatha (three) : 3 angles

- arbaa (four) : 4 angles

- ...

- achra (ten) : 10 (the famous arba's zero, at the right of course, 
literary sense of packet or group)

- ihda achra (eleven) : 11 (one-ten, from right to left, so first units 
than tens)

- ithna achra (twelve) : 12(two-ten)

- thalatha achra (thirteen) : 13 (three-ten)

- ...

- ichroune (twenty) : 20 (literary sense of the 2 packets of ten)

- thalathoune (thirty) : 30 (idem)

- ...

- mia (hundred) : 100 (convention)

- alf ( thousand) : 1000 (idem)

- milione or alf-alf (milion) : 1000 000 (milion or thousand of thousand)

- ...

example : 103423 (mia thalatha alf, arbaa mia thalatha wa ichroune) = 
(hundred three thousand, four hundred, three and twenty),

how?

from right to left (like computer's method) :

- 3 than 2 so : 3 units and 2 tens, we say three and twenty, than

- 4 so : four hundred, than

- 3 so : three thousands, than

- 0 so : no tens of thousands, than

- 1 so : we have 1 hundred of thousands.

finaly, I think that german and arab methods are very similar and from my 
point of view they are more logical and less complicated than other methods.

top_comment.text:
There's a small french community in the south-west of Nova Scotia, Canada, 
that says their 70+ numbers differently than this norm. Instead of 
Soixante-dix (sixty and ten) for 70, they say "septante", continuing the 
style from 30, 40, 50, 60 said in the way you've mentioned here (trente, 
quarante, cinquante, soixante).  So they say "septante, huinante, neunante" 
(for 70, 80, 90).  And it carries on like septante-et-un, septante-deux, 
etc (71, 72). Freaky, eh?!  Many of the Acadian French communities in 
south-west Nova Scotia have a fairly different dialect than the 
'traditional' Acadian style French language that is known across the rest 
of Eastern Canada, and there are definitely MANY different slangs, 
pronunciations, words, and expressions entirely, compared to Ontario or 
Quebec French-speaking provinces and communities.﻿

captions.text:
PAUL SMITH: And then when they
get to 70, that's where the

big problems start, because the
French haven't invented a
word for 70.

BRADY HARAN: I always assume the
one thing that is kind of

international is numbers,
mathematics.

That's the one thing that
is the same everywhere.

You're about to ruin
this, aren't you?
PAUL SMITH: Yes, I am.

One thing that you learn when
you're studying a foreign

language is that counting
systems are very different.

And, in fact, it's one of the
ways that you can tell if

somebody's a really good speaker
of a foreign language.

You can really tell what their
real mother tongue is when

they start counting, because
even if somebody operates, you

know, an English person living
in France, when they start

counting to themselves, they'll
probably count to
themselves in English.

They're our closest neighbors,
so you'd have thought that

maybe they'd count in
the same way as us.

But one of the things that I
have to keep repeating to my

students is that, in fact,
the French don't
count in the same way.

And they use numbers in very
different ways in a whole

range of different everyday
environments.
Let me give you some examples.

So the French-- well, what do
we do in England when we're
counting numbers?

We give numbers, the first 12
numbers when we're counting,
we give them individual names.
So we go 1 to 12.

And then we slip into a thing
where we go 13, 14, which is

kind of 3 and 10, 4 and
10, and so forth.

The French start off in a
slightly different way.
They go a bit further.

Un, deux, trois, quatre, cinq,
six, sept, huit, neuf, dix,

onze, douze, treize, quatorze,
quinze, seize.

And then they go for our 17,
dix-sept, 10-7; dix-huit,

10-8; dix-neuf, 10-9; and
then vingt for 20.

It's very similar, the
counting system
after that, to English.

So they go on to 20, as
I said was vingt.
Then they go to 30, trente.
Quarante for 40.
Cinquante for 50.
Soixante for 60.

And then when they get to 70,
that's where the big problems

start, because the
French haven't
invented a word for 70.

Instead what they do is they
count to 60 and add 10.

So whereas we go to 60 and then
go to 70, a French person

goes to 60, but then goes to 60
plus 10, because they say
soixante-dix.
Soixante-dix is 70 in French.

Soixante-dix literally means
60-10, but it means 70.

Oh, they know what
the number 70 is.

They don't sort of do
this plus business.

And a French person, when they
hear you say soixante-dix,

they don't think, oh,
that's 60 and 10.
They see 70.

So the mental picture that is
conjured by the sound of

soixante-dix is still 70,
the same as we would.

And then they continue by
instead of say-- they haven't

invented a word, for
example, for 71.

So that's soixante et onze,
literally 60 and 11.

It's rather odd with these
ones that they
say soixante et onze--
"et" is the word for "and"--

because when they get to 72,
they just say soixante-douze.
Soixante-douze, 60-12.

And it's only when we're dealing
with ones that they
use the "et."

But it gets even more confusing
from the English

point of view, because you
think, OK, so we've got

Soixante et onze,
soixante-douze,

soixante-treize,
soixante-quatorze,

soixante-quinze,
soixante-seize,

soixante-dix-sept,
soixante-dix-huit,
soixante-dix-neuf.

What do they do when
they get to 80?

Surely they've got
a word for 80.
Well, no.

Because the French, when they
get to that number, they say

quatre-vingts, which
means 4 20s.

Well, that's what it means,
4 20s, literally.

The French, of course, when they
hear quatre-vingts, see
80 in their minds.

And then they go
quatre-vingt-un, 4 20s, 1.
BRADY HARAN: Not 4 20s and 1?
PAUL SMITH: No.
They'd just be-- ah.

The reason they don't say 4 20s
and 1 is because it's too
many words.

So there's also a style issue
here, because, you know, the
French love their style.

But what they do do then, and
this is the other weird thing,

when they get to 90, they still
haven't even thought of

another word for 90 or
a decent word for 90.
So what do they say?

They say quatre-vingt-dix,
4 20s, 10.

And then when they get
to 91, they say
quatre-vingt-onze, 4 20s, 11.
92 is quatre-vingt-douze.
93 is quatre-vingt-treize.
94 is quatre-vingt-quatorze.
95, quatre-vingt-quinze.

And so it goes, until
they get up to 100.

And they have invented
a word for 100.
So 100 is cent.

One of the big problems, of
course, with this kind of

numbering system is when you're
listening to somebody

giving you a phone number,
because if
I could just explain--

let me think of an English
phone number.

So you might have 0115, so
that's your Nottingham code.

Then you'd have 962 would be the
subcode for the exchange.

And then the individual
number would be 5782.

And in English, we would read
out all of the numbers,

0-1-1-5, or we might say
0-double 1-5, 962, 5782.

BRADY HARAN: This isn't a real
number, by the way, is it?
PAUL SMITH: No, no.
I just made that one up.
OK.

So that's an example of an
English telephone number.

But in France, they do it
completely differently.

They will take the numbers and
they will say they will

actually distinguish the
numbers 62, 58, 49, 27.

And when you ask somebody for
their phone number, they will

tell you that it is
62, 58, 49, 27.
They won't say--

BRADY HARAN: They'll do that
for all numbers, will they?

PAUL SMITH: They'll do that
for all telephone numbers.
They won't say 625-849-27.

And this causes not big
problems, but if you're on the

telephone to a client in France
who wants your mobile

number and you're used to giving
your mobile number in

the way the English do and then
you try to do it to the

French, they find that very
difficult to cope with.

And it works in the
other direction.

My students are endlessly
telling me about the problems

they had copying down
telephone numbers.

And of course, the really big
problems start when you get to

numbers that start with
a 6, with a 7, with an
8, and with a 9.

So it's a problem, because
if you're English
and you hear soixante--

let's remember that numbers,
what we would call 60 to 69,
start with the word soixante.
But so do numbers 70 to 79.

Let's say that your friend
starts saying "my number is"--

I'll say it in French,
"mon numero, c'est
soixante" you start--
you do that.

And then they say "et onze" and
you have to go back and

correct it, because it's not
soixante at all, it's 71.

But the other thing that the
French do with numbers while

we're on the subject, that's the
French for "10 point 69."

Let's say that that's the world
record for the women's

100 meters dash in
the Olympics.

Now you can see that's very
different from the way that we
would write it in English.

It's also very different from
the way that we would say it.

There we've got a
decimal point.

And the French are
using a comma.

But they also say
it differently.

In English we say "10 point 69,"
because we separate the
tenths and the hundredths.

But the French would
say "10 comma 69."

So you have to listen
now very carefully.

If you're watching a French
sports commentary, for

example, if you're watching the
Olympic Games in France

and you're trying to catch the
time, you have to listen out

for not 10 point 69, but "dix
virgule soixante-neuf," "10

comma 69." So once again,
you've got this issue of

numbers being grouped
together.

And that's something the
French do all the time.

They don't separate individual
numbers out.

They group them and
use their name.

The word the French use for a
comma is "virgule." And they

use that in grammar as they
use it in numbers as well.

So when a French person reads
out this time, then they will
say "dix virgule"--
comma--
"soixante-neuf."

BRADY HARAN: To a French person,
is that "10 point 695"
or is that 10,695?

PAUL SMITH: It's 10,
virgule, 695.

So it would be "dix virgule six
cent quatre-vingt-quinze."

That would be the way
they express it.

BRADY HARAN: How would a French
person write 10,695?

PAUL SMITH: Well, they would
either just do that--

and very often they
leave a space.

In a French textbook you might
find there's a space between
the thousands and the 695.

Or occasionally, this is going
to confuse you, just
occasionally they'll do that.

So in fact, you could say that
the French and the English do
exactly the opposite thing.

And you could argue that it's
just to confuse each other and
it's deliberate.

Well, I don't have a problem
with it, but it has caused
problems in the past.

There was a rather unfortunate
case in a French hospital a

few years ago where there
was a serious--

too large a dose of something
was administered to patients

simply because of a misreading
of a decimal point for this,

or a comma not being read
the right way round.

So it can be a big problem
in technical translation.

Technical translators need to
be absolutely sure that they

get it right, because
otherwise it can
go very, very wrong.

BRADY HARAN: If you'd like to
hear a bit more about French

numbers, including why it's
impossible to score 20 out of

20 in France, check out another
video we've got here

on "Numberphile." Or if you'd
just like to hear more about

languages in general from people
like Paul and others,

check out another channel I've
got called "Words of the

World." It's got all sorts of
fascinating videos about

things like California
or biscuit or vodka.

There's loads of videos on there
already and there's new

ones going on every week,
so maybe subscribe.
